newsitem.title: SPAIN: Argentaria to use 96 profits to cut costs.
newsitem.headline: Argentaria to use 96 profits to cut costs.

text.p: Spain's Corporacion Bancaria de Espana (Argentaria) said on Wednesday it would used 42 billion pesetas from this year's profits to reduce its financial costs.
"We want to anticipate the future in order to increase financial margin and the dividend in the next few years," chairman Francisco Gonzalez said in a press statement.
The Bank of Spain and the banking group's external auditors had approved the decision, aimed at "maximising shareholder value", the chairman said.

Given the effective savings this will produce, Argentaria said it will propose to the general shareholders' meeting a total dividend of 277 pesetas gross per share against 1996 results, of which 128 pesetas were already paid in October. 1995's total dividend was 270 pesetas.
The bank also said the board had named Francisco Gomez Roldan CEO for the group, and Ramon Bustamente as non-executive vice-chairman.

1996 earnings would be used to "drastically reduce the average interest rate on large-scale liabilities taken on at fixed and long-term interest rates", as part of the strategy to strengthen the group, the note said.
The move will "significantly improve net interest income and profits in 1997 and following years, as well as ROE and earnings per share," the bank said.
